i
Ro
m
23 January to my L. Trea
s
B e lgia: 1591: Ja
n
May yt please yo
r
good L. I have yet no answere from
the
States
to her
Ma
t
laste letters, For either they
come not together, or their nomb
r
is not competent
or somwhat els is p
r
tended, in excuse of theyr delay.
But yet I think er bee long; I shall know their
resolution in one sort or oth
r
.
Mons
r
Busenval
hath deliv
r
ed a l
re
to
e
Councell of State
from
Mareschal Biron
, wherin they are intreated to
hibit
the marchant
of these countreys to transport theyr
commodities to any towne of the Ligue in
Normandy
and
Picardy,
but that all may bee discharged
in
Caen
& in
Diepe,
where theyr vent, gain & paym
t
shalbee every waie as courrant as yt should bee oth
r
wise,
The
King
by that meanes in raising an imposte
upon such kinde of m
r
chandise, &
mitting a free
traffique between his subject
& the leagieurs
shall enforce his ennemies in those quarters, to
seek their provision from the foresaid 2 townes, &
make a benefit therby, for the bett
r
mainten
a
ce of
his Army. It is a motion that must go to the
Provinces, for w
ch
they cannot yet resolve.
Mons
r
de Turen
de
ted from
Arnham
ten daies
ago, & as it is thought is come very neer to his
Journeys end. The bearer hereof
M
r
Wiat
can advertise yo
r
L of all the
ticularities
wherof
The freebooting voyage of
Count Overstein
wherw
th
in a former I acquainted yo
r
L. Having no other
matter that is of any worth I send yo
r
L. heerw
th
an extract of c
r
taine l
res
intercepted w
ch
were
writen from some
sons of quality to
e Gouverno
r
[of]
Gertrudenbergh.
onely so much is copied as se
[ems]
materiall,
And so I take my humble leave
Ja
n
23 90.
